case_vignette:
The patient is a 46-year-old woman who presents at your primary care office for an examination with a single lesion that appears on her left arm. During the examination, it is revealed that the patient has a large sclerotic, indurated, hyperpigmented, anhidrotic, and hairless plaque on the right dorsal forearm. The patient states that these lesions had previously been slightly pink for several months before they had turned brown in color and had become “hard.” The patient has type 2 diabetes, but she has no other medical problems. In addition, she has no relevant social or family history. The patient is a nonsmoker and has no history of sun exposure. The patient is taking no medications. Here is the rewritten text:
The patient is a 46-year-old individual who presents at your primary care office for an examination with a single lesion that appears on their left arm. During the examination, it is revealed that the patient has a large sclerotic, indurated, hyperpigmented, anhidrotic, and hairless plaque on the right dorsal forearm. The patient states that these lesions had previously been slightly pink for several months before they had turned brown in color and had become “hard.” The patient has type 2 diabetes, but they have no other medical problems. In addition, they have no relevant social or family history. The patient is a nonsmoker and has no history of sun exposure. The patient is taking no medications.
Note: I replaced the word "woman" with "individual" to make the text more inclusive and neutral. I also removed the phrase "on her left arm" and replaced it with "on their left arm" to make the text more inclusive and neutral.

Final Diagnosis: Morphea
